arm_group.arm_group_label: Fiberoptic Intubation performed by an expert
arm_group.description: Tracheal intubation will be performed by an expert anesthesia attending with and without use of the air-Q

arm_group.arm_group_label: Fiberoptic Intubation performed by a novice
arm_group.description: Tracheal intubation will be performed by an anesthesia trainee with and without use of the air-Q

brief_summary.textblock:
The goal of this prospective randomized study is to compare the effect of operator
      experience on the ability to use fiberoptic-guided intubation in children less than two
      years old, with and without the use of an air-Q as a conduit. The question the investigators
      are trying to answer is: Does the operator experience make a significant difference in the
      time for successful fiberoptic guided tracheal intubation with and without the use of an
      air-Q intubating laryngeal airway?

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Fiberoptic Intubation With Fiberoptic Intubation Through an Air-Q Intubating Laryngeal Airway in Infants and Small Children

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of this study is to compare the effect of operator experience on the ability to use
      fiberoptic-guided intubation in children less than two years old, with and without the use
      of an air-Q as a conduit. The ease and time for placement of the air-Q, fiberoptic grade of
      laryngeal view, time for fiberoptic tracheal intubation, and peri-operative complications
      will also be assessed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy (ASA I to III) children who will be intubated as part of their general
             anesthesia plan for their scheduled surgeries

          -  Age 1 month - 2 years

          -  Weight 1-20 Kg

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Children with active respiratory infection

          -  Known history of difficult mask ventilation

          -  Diagnosis of a congenital syndrome associated with difficult airway management

          -  Airway abnormalities (e.g., laryngomalacia, subglottic stenosis).

Fiberoptic Intubation performed by a novice
intervention.other_name: Device will be placed and fiberoptic tracheal intubation will be performed and timed. Laryngeal grade of view will also be assessed

facility.name: Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Comparison of Free-handed Fiberoptic Intubation Compared With Fiberoptic Intubation Through an Air-QTM Intubating Laryngeal Airway in Children Less Than Two Years of Age: Does Operator Experience Affect Time to Successful Tracheal Intubation?

overall_official.affiliation: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago
Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

primary_outcome.description: The time for successful intubation will be from removal of the face mask or disconnection of the circuit from the air-Q until evidence of end-tidal CO2 is confirmed.
primary_outcome.measure: Time for successful fiberoptic tracheal intubation
primary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

reference.citation: Hodzovic I, Janakiraman C, Sudhir G, Goodwin N, Wilkes AR, Latto IP. Fibreoptic intubation through the laryngeal mask airway: effect of operator experience*. Anaesthesia. 2009 Oct;64(10):1066-71. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2044.2009.06030.x.
Hodzovic I, Petterson J, Wilkes AR, Latto IP. Fibreoptic intubation using three airway conduits in a manikin: the effect of operator experience. Anaesthesia. 2007 Jun;62(6):591-7.
Erb T, Marsch SC, Hampl KF, Frei FJ. Teaching the use of fiberoptic intubation for children older than two years of age. Anesth Analg. 1997 Nov;85(5):1037-41.

Jagannathan N, Kozlowski RJ, Sohn LE, Langen KE, Roth AG, Mukherji II, Kho MF, Suresh S. A clinical evaluation of the intubating laryngeal airway as a conduit for tracheal intubation in children. Anesth Analg. 2011 Jan;112(1):176-82. doi: 10.1213/ANE.0b013e3181fe0408. Epub 2010 Nov 16.

secondary_outcome.description: Successful placement of the air-Q will start with the removal of the facemask until presence of end-tidal CO2 is confirmed.
secondary_outcome.measure: Time to successful placement of the Air-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

secondary_outcome.description: Number of attempts needed for successful placement will be recorded (maximum of 3 attempts will be considered as a failure)
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of attempts to place the Air-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

secondary_outcome.description: The ease for Air-Q placement will be assessed using a subjective scale
secondary_outcome.measure: Ease for placement of the air-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

secondary_outcome.description: The laryngeal alignment through the devices will be graded using an established scoring system
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

secondary_outcome.description: Includes: Complications during the placement of the Air-Q (Laryngospasm, Bronchospasm, Desaturation, etc. Oropharyngolaryngeal morbidity at discharge, participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an average of 24 hours. Oropharyngolaryngeal morbidity at 24 hours post-operatively, measured at 24 hours after device placement/study initiation. These will be assessed by the subject's response or parents subjective assesment to standardized questions regarding oropharyngeal complaints such as sore throat, jaw pain, neck discomfort.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at 24 hours after device placement/study initiation

secondary_outcome.description: Number of attempts needed for successful fiberoptic tracheal intubation will be recorded (maximum of 3 attempts will be considered as a failure)
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of attempts for fiberoptic tracheal intubation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours

secondary_outcome.description: The ease for fiberoptic tracheal intubation will be assessed using a subjective scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
